text: this is get eaten for the New York Times
losing a little weight is something we
all try at one time or another for my
body and lifestyle the app breeze which
is free for iPhones really does work in
essence it's a step an activity counter
based on the oft-quoted idea that you
should walk around 10,000 steps a day to
help keep your weight down and you in
shape breeze basically monitors whether
you're walking enough and gently prompts
you with cheerful reminders if you've
done well or if you still need to walk a
little bit extra to achieve your daily
goal it's simple highly motivational and
I find its gentle prompts really do keep
me on target the app only works on
iphone 5s and more recent ones but if
you're looking for a slightly more
full-featured weight loss app you should
check out lose it which is free for iOS
and Android lose it tries to be a
one-stop shop for smartphone users who
are trying to lose weight effectively
acting as a calorie counter a dietary
advice database and a fitness and
activity tracker to do this it requires
a little bit of input from you mainly in
the form of tagging how many calories
you're eating in a particular meal the
app tries to help with this task vieira
vast database of calories in particular
meals and a barcode scanner for when
you're cooking your own food but while
core features of the app are free to get
access to all of them such as an
analytics section to help you find out
where all your calories are coming from
you have to pay up to forty dollars per
year so a great alternative to this app
albeit one that's slightly simpler is my
fitness pals calorie counter this app is
completely free for iOS and Android and
has many of the same features as the
previous app including the ability to
connect to third-party fitness tracking
devices it has a slightly plain
interface but don't let that put you off
and above all remember that to use any
of these apps you really get the most
out of them when you're committed to
losing weight and getting a little bit
fitter
